awd_titl_txt: Gauging Continuity and Change with the General Social Survey
awd_abstract_narration:
This project adds questions to the 2020 General Social Survey (GSS) to look at the changing shape of faith-related attitudes and behaviors in America.  Over the past thirty years, the landscape of these attitudes and behaviors in America has dramatically changed.  While the broad contours of these changes have been captured by public opinion surveys, their causes and consequences often remain underexplored because of the limits of current survey data. The GSS is a publicly available data source, which means that any scholar interested in the study of faith-related attitudes and behaviors and culture can draw on these questions.

Through this project, a battery of approximately 40-50 survey questions about faith-related attitudes and behaviors will be included on the 2020 GSS. The GSS is an ideal instrument through which to examine this changing landscape and its connection to broader cultural values for a number of reasons.  First, the GSS remains the gold standard in survey research, with an exceptionally high response rate (above 60 percent) and interviews that are conducted face to face on a nationally representative sample of Americans.  Second, the GSS already has a wide variety of questions relating to faith and on other social, cultural, and political attitudes. In combination with these already existing questions, our module will allow scholars to tap into different aspects of attachments, beliefs, and attitudes related to faith, and to uncover important variation among Americans.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The singular goal of our NSF project was to include additional survey questions to the 2020 General Social Survey (GSS). In particular, we wanted to ask questions about religious attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors in order to better understand America’s fast-changing and complicated religious landscape. By proposing questions for inclusion on the GSS, we opened the door for scholars to answer hundreds of questions about the intersection between religion and society. These questions will allow scholars to understand how religion influences—and is influenced by—social, cultural, and political attitudes and behaviors.

 

NORC, the organizers of the GSS, faced numerous challenges when trying to field the 2020 survey. Most notably, the COVID-19 pandemic made it unsafe for GSS enumerators to go into people's homes and conduct in-person surveys. This unexpected hurdle forced the GSS organizers to delay fielding the survey and pivot to an online format. This eleventh hour change came with a host of logistical problems, including (but not limited to) developing a sample frame and weighting scheme to produce public opinion data that matched the U.S. population and modifying questions to make sense to respondents taking the survey online. 

 

Despite these challenges, there is a publicly available 2021 GSS module for scholars to use, including 3,500 responses to eight additional mini-modules that ask about questions related to religion. The new questions ask about: religious identification, group attachment to one’s religion, evangelical beliefs, spirituality, secular beliefs, abortion identities, and Christian nationalism attitudes. These questions, alongside the existing social, political, and religious GSS questions, allow researchers to make sense of America’s unique religious environment. Survey researchers often “make do” with the questions available to them, but this causes the quality of scholarship to suffer and limits what readers can take away from the findings. These additional questions tapping into many aspects of the American religious experience are currently providing scholars in sociology, political science, economics, and religion the opportunity to understand how people think about their faith in ways that have not been previously available.
